RelatedSentence: SAN FRANCISCO ( MarketWatch ) - Gold prices settled with a slight gain on Monday , finding some support from weakness in the U.S. dollar but failing to reclaim the $ 1,300 level as investors looked ahead to speeches from Federal Reserve officials and minutes from the central bank this week .

Gold for June delivery US : GCM4 edged up by 40 cents to settle at $ 1,293.80 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange , after tapping a high of $ 1,305.70 in electronic trading .
Prices , which have n't closed above $ 1,300 since Wednesday , lost a total of roughly 0.9 % on Thursday and Friday .

Gold has been fairly quiet this year , and we anticipate for the short term gold to hover around $ 1,300 , which seems to be a key magnet level , said analysts at Lido Isle Advisors , in a note Monday .

RelatedSentence: Gold ended last week on a low note , at $ 1,293.40 an ounce , but prices notched a gain for the week amid a flood of mixed economic news .
Dallas Fed President Richard Fisher and San Francisco Fed President John Williams took part in a panel discussion on monetary policy in Dallas Monday .
Williams said the Fed will probably start lifting interest rates next year .
Williams said the Fed will probably start lifting interest rates next year .
Williams said the Fed will probably start lifting interest rates next year .
Elsewhere in metals trading , July platinum US : PLN4  rose $ 4.10 , or 0.3 % , to $ 1,470.20 an ounce while June palladium US : PAM4  added 60 cents , or 0.1 % , to $ 815.60 an ounce .
Elsewhere in metals trading , July platinum US : PLN4  rose $ 4.10 , or 0.3 % , to $ 1,470.20 an ounce while June palladium US : PAM4  added 60 cents , or 0.1 % , to $ 815.60 an ounce .

In related gold news Monday , the European Central Bank and other central banks reached a new Central Bank Gold Agreement - the fourth of its kind - marking a commitment to preserve the clarity and transparency the pact provides for gold - market participants .

In related gold news Monday , the European Central Bank and other central banks reached a new Central Bank Gold Agreement - the fourth of its kind - marking a commitment to preserve the clarity and transparency the pact provides for gold - market participants .
Those that signed the pact noted that they do not have any current plans to sell significant announces of gold .

In a statement following the central banks ' announcement , the World Gold Council pointed out that over the last 5 years , major gold holders from European central banks have virtually stopped all gold sales - selling less than 25 metric tons of gold against an agreed limit of 2,000 metric tons .
